awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Cyber Physical Solution for High Penetration Renewables in Smart Grid
awd_abstract_narration:
Effective integration of large amounts of renewable energy into the grid is of utmost importance for sustainable future and greener smart cities.   Due to the unpredictable variations in weather, over 80% of the available renewable energy from solar and wind sources cannot be harnessed effectively.  Large scale and cost-effective integration of photovoltaic energy into the smart grid is challenging due to: (a) unpredictability and intermittency of weather pattern, (b) fast morning ramp up and afternoon ramp down of solar generation that triggers instabilities in the grid, (c) unavailability of solar generation at sun down requiring the need for locational energy storage facilities, and (d) lack of technologies for efficient and intelligent on-demand sharing of solar generation with conventional power generation in the grid. Current technologies of solar integration are based on unreliable weather prediction and ineffective load sharing that make the overall grid performance unreliable and inefficient, thus necessitating the need for a broader outlook of the whole picture.    

This research brings a holistic vision of the future smart grid as a synergistic integration of its various components with novel computational tools for forecasting and intelligent load sharing with distributed energy storage. The study collects real-time Photovoltaic (PV) data from the plant, conducts high-end modeling, analysis and visualization on various datasets to understand, predict and mitigate the system instabilities and fluctuations triggered by PV intermittencies.  This solution can be used in the planning process at the command and control centers for electric utilities.

The developed approach, which is an adaptive, resilient, efficient and effective integration of renewables, will be applicable broadly in the energy sector thereby reducing carbon footprint and making the system stable under expected high penetration of renewable sources and unanticipated intermittencies. This solution fills the gap that will help our nation steer closer to the ultimate goal of a sustainable future involving a smart clean power grid. This project will pursue several outreach activities to engage with students from underrepresented groups.

por.por_cntn:
All five proposed goals have been vigorously pursued by FIU throughout this award and have been completed. FIU has perfected methods for effectively handling PV intermittency.The results on the basis of theoretical and experimental work from this effort motivated us to develop different products that could help communities implement more renewable technologies. The products resulted in patents that were based on machine learning methods utilizing solar PV data addressing intermittency issues (11022720, 1095821, 10326280). There are a lot of minute-to-minute factors (including weather, soiling, shading, DC-AC conversion efficiency, and other derate factors) that affect its generation profile; thus, any fluctuations in the profile need to be corrected as soon as possible. A study was performed through the implementation of battery-supercapacitor hybrid storage systems that can compensate for the moderate-to-severe ramps of PV, the interconnection of multiple geographically separated PV systems to form an aggregated fleet that can transact energy between each other in response to availability and demand, or through some combination of these methods.

A power quality detection system was developed using Support Vector Machine (SVM) algorithm that was able to detect any existence of any disturbances in real-time. We developed an algorithm that can forecast PV generation, and site-level weather data and are capable of generating historical generation data. Moreover, we developed a prototype of a smart load of the future that may have an effect on smart grids with high penetration of photovoltaics, and a study on the feasibility & significance of the future spread of smart loads on high penetration smart grids was performed. We identified problems and research areas for Internet of Things networks for smart grids, including scenarios that incorporate future smart loads and intermittently high penetrations of renewable sources, and analyzed the impacts of high PV penetration on the power quality and voltage profiles along the connected feeders.

 Other outcomes of this project include a review of the requirements, specifications, and technologies that are necessary to facilitate the high penetration of distributed renewables in the future; developing a strategy that is both formal and standardized for managing the different data measured from grid-connected PV systems with high penetration; and solutions to power quality problems caused by intermittent, high-penetration grid-connected solar PV systems, including the use of smart technologies; development of A Tri-Modular Framework to Minimize Smart Grid Cyber-Attack Cognitive Gap in Utility Control Centers; evolutionary algorithm based model for optimal smart inverter volt-VAR curve selection. Additionally, a genetic algorithm-based multi-objection optimization technique for Volt-VAR control with high PV penetration.  We looked at the challenges created by large-scale PV renewable energy integration and how these obstacles can be overcome with the help of energy storage. During this project, studies were performed that described a detailed architecture of the framework’s three modules, DM, CM, and AM, detailing how they can be realized and which human users within the utility CCC would be the potential users. The designed framework reduces the cognitive gap through its three modules and increases situational awareness. Also, a comprehensive study presented challenges and mitigation methods in high-penetration photovoltaic generation. During the course of this project, machine learning tools such as SVM, unsupervised learning, and artificial neural networks were used in multiple tasks to achieve the proposed goal. Additionally, models were built to anticipate the charge level in Li-ion batteries, and the innovative FACTS approach was provided to handle the cybersecurity issue in the BMS (Battery Management System) of the electric vehicle. In addition, various AC/DC converter topologies for bidirectional power flow were reviewed, and a study was conducted on how solar fleets are aggregated. Protecting the smart grid at times of significant penetration of renewables was also the subject of extensive research. Multiple courses were developed with the inclusion of the work from this project.

The effort resulted in industry funding support that helped us build one of its kind state-of-the-art infrastructure at FIU. The Artificial Intelligence Renewable (AIR) Microgrid facility is equipped with the following core infrastructure: 1) 3 MW-9 MWHr Storage, 3.35 MVA grid forming (GFM) inverter, 1.4 MW grid-tied PV array, multiple other generators. 2) 1 MW dynamic load for testing and trials with more than 15 feeders direct access data, 46 PV inverters with bi-directional control. This Hybrid Photo Voltaic Power (HPVP) plant can also work as a microgrid, allowing powering up the Engineering Center loads and is connected to the grid. It has features for dynamic isolation and the black start.

More than 50 students went through the learnings from this project. All of them graduated with at least one job in the energy sector. Many of the students were from the minority community. Overall, the project has helped the scientific community and general population the better use of renewable resources along with modern-day tools developed from the proposed project.
